title: Breakfast changes
body: It’s time to change up your breakfast!
summary:
We’re changing breakfast as you might know it!

Research shows us that breakfast is the most important meal when it comes to:
  • Our insulin activity
  • Stabilizing blood sugar levels across the day
  • Reducing high levels of androgens
All which cause a lot of our PCOS symptoms, and which can influence our ovulation and periods

Both what we eat and when we eat are important in influencing these factors,
therefore we recommend consuming a nourishing breakfast within 1 hour of waking

title: Changes Table
body:
We want you to focus on these key changes at breakfast:
  • Consuming 40-50g of protein at breakfast
  • Reducing carbohydrates at breakfast to a minimal amount
  • Ideally eating within 1 hour of waking
As well as:
  • Adding in as many non-starchy vegetables when you can
  • Incorporating some healthy fats
summary:
Why?

+ Protein acts as a good blood sugar stabilizer which is important for managing insulin,
3pm energy slumps, sugar cravings and hangry attacks. Protein is also proven to be satiating.

- Carbohydrates cause a rise in blood sugar and insulin much more than protein or fat.
So reducing carbs also helps stabilize our blood sugars and manage our insulin.

+ Non-starchy veggies provide nutrients, fiber, satiety and of course flavor,
and have relatively little impact on our blood sugars or energy intake.

+ Some healthy fats also for blood sugar stabilization and satiety among other benefits.

title: Protein
body:
Big change 1, Protein: 
You’re going to be increasing your protein intake at breakfast to 40-50 grams. This may sound daunting, but we promise you’ll get the hang of it!

This is by no means a high protein diet, many of us just aren’t eating enough protein.

For context, one egg is only 7 grams of protein.

So a breakfast of two eggs and toast isn’t as high in protein as we’ve been led to believe!

You may need to increase the protein in your breakfast gradually, and it might take some trial and error to find out what breakfasts work for you. So don’t be hard on yourself if you have a few breakfasts that flop, you’ll get there! If you feel stuck in your old habits or routine, remember you can ‘unhook’ from this thought.
Let’s focus on the towards moves and steps in the right direction that you are making to get closer to your goal and being true to your WHY!

title: Carbs
body:
Big change 2, Carbs:
You’ll aim to reduce carb intake as much as possible at breakfast.

This can be by: 
  • Incorporating plenty of non-starchy vegetables in their place
  • Avoid starchy vegetables
  • Avoid fruit (with the exception berries)
  • Avoid grains and legumes
This isn’t a low-carb nutrition plan - we’re simply keeping carbohydrates low at breakfast for the reasons mentioned above.
If reducing your carbs right down initially sounds too daunting, start slow! Even reducing by 1 piece of toast is still a towards move. In another week’s time you might be ready to reduce the second!

title: Timing
body:
Big change 3, Breakfast timing:

Aim to have your breakfast within an hour of waking.

This may be a big change for those of you that have previously been fasting,
or just not eating breakfast, however it is important. So if you need to, slowly work up to it.

title: Breakfast Timing BOOSTER
How to increase your protein intake
body:
Ideally, try to hit that 40-50g protein right from the start

The closer you get to this, the better it’ll help manage that insulin and therefore start addressing those symptoms.  

But if you’re sitting here wondering how on earth you're going to meet your protein targets, especially if you’ve been fasting or aren’t a huge breakfast eater, then we have some top tips for you!

title: 1. Try a gradual increase
body:
If you’re fresh into the breakfast game, or suffer from early morning nausea then start small and build yourself up towards the protein goal.


You don’t go for one run and decide you are ready for a marathon right?! This takes time and training, as you build up your fitness. The same analogy can be applied with your protein breakfast - take your time to build up to the stretch goal of 40-50g.

Every breakfast you have with additional protein is a towards move, helping you live the life you want to live and controlling your PCOS and root cause.

title: 2. Mix & Match Protein Sources
body: You don't have to get your protein from just one source, you can easily mix and match a few different foods in order to reach that goal.
summary:
+ Aim to get as much protein from food sources

+ Look to protein powder as a supplement to top up your protein

title: 3. Know that this high protein goal is not forever
body:
You won’t need to reach the high protein goal for the rest of your days, we just ask that you give it a good try for the next few months in an attempt to really stabilize your insulin responses. After this you can explore your personal sweet spot with how much protein satiates you comfortably.

Remember that towards moves, such as gradually increasing your protein, can be hard! We may not get instant gratification, but our future self will thank us for making these steps. 

If this seems hard, let’s reflect on what is keeping you stuck?
You can choose to let these thoughts hook you, and drag you into an away move, or we can choose to see these thoughts for what they are and make a towards move.

title: Smoothie Builder
body: Here's a handy guide on how to build a satiating and balanced smoothie!

title: Breakfast Builder
body: Here are some guidelines on how to build and create your breakfast.

title: Protein Powder
body:
Protein powder is a great way to hit that protein goal, particularly if you’re vegetarian or vegan, you’re short on time in the morning, or you haven’t been a breakfast eater previously.  

But, not all protein is made the same.

Follow our 5-step checklist to help you locate a quality protein powder.

1. Protein source

We recommend picking from one of the following:
  • Pea
  • Collagen
  • Egg White
  • Beef Protein Isolate
  • Hemp Protein
  • Pea + Rice Protein Blend


Avoid:
  • Whey (a by-product of dairy milk that can stimulate insulin)

title: Protein Powder
body:
2. Sweeteners

Best: Opt for an unsweetened protein powder, or one using either stevia extract, monk fruit extract or thaumatin as these sweeteners come from natural sources and don’t stimulate a high insulin response.  

Okay: Sugar alcohols are better than artificial sweeteners, but not ideal. These are mannitol, sorbitol, xylitol, lactitol, maltitol (typically ending in ‘-itol’), isomalt, allulose and hydrogenated starch hydrolysates (HSH).

Avoid: Artificial sweeteners which are chemically produced compounds, including maltodextrin, dextrin, aspartame (e951), sucralose (e955), saccharin (e954), neotame and acesulfame potassium.

title: Protein Powder
body:
3. Food additives

Fine to use: Guar gum, xanthan gum or organic gum acacia - these are thickening agents from natural sources

Avoid: Artificial colours and sweeteners, anti-caking or emulsifiers, fillers such as cellulose or vegetable oils - these ingredients typically suggest a highly processed, poor quality protein powder



4. Carbohydrates

As we’re limiting our carbohydrate intake at breakfast to avoid a big insulin spike in the morning, we suggest opting for a low carbohydrate option.

Check the nutrition panel per serve and aim for:
 
Best: Less than 2 grams per serve
Okay: Less than 4 grams per serve

title: Protein Powder
body:
5. Taste


Find a protein powder that you enjoy!

If you hate the taste of your protein powder, you’re not going to use it. It might take a bit of trial and error to find your favorite and that’s okay!

Tip: Most companies offer a sample size for a fraction of the price of a tub. So if you can, taste test some of the sample sachets before investing in a whole tub.


If you have a protein that doesn’t fit the guidelines suggested, finish that before purchasing a new tub. There’s no need to waste it!

title: Vegetarian, Vegan or Plant-Based
body:
We understand many people enjoy eating plant-based, vegan and vegetarian.

Whilst these ways of eating may be more important for you for sustainability and animal welfare reasons, and although they can be incredibly healthy (due to eating more whole foods, vegetables, whole grains and nuts and seeds), exclusively eating this way might not be the healthiest option for everyone.

We want to maximize the variety in your diet, while still maintaining a predominantly whole-foods based diet.

This doesn’t mean you can’t enjoy vegetarian or vegan meals, just that strictly following these eating patterns does require careful planning.

title: Carbohydrates
body:
Things to take into consideration: Carbs

Plant-based protein sources tend to be much higher in carbohydrates, and lower in protein than animal-based products such as legumes and legume based products, so if you are following a plant-based diet it will be worth having a look into this.


As we suspect insulin plays a big role in driving your PCOS symptoms, eating to best manage and improve our insulin sensitivity may make it more restrictive for you when following a strictly plant-based diet.

As we know carbohydrates raise our insulin more so than protein and fat, we do need to be cautious of our overall carbohydrate intake when focusing on our insulin sensitivity.

This doesn’t mean carbs are bad and we can’t have them!

Carbs are important for our body to function well (including menstruation!). We just need to be a bit more smart about our carb intake to maintain a more stable blood sugar, thus helping our insulin manage the load.

Top tip: Tofu and tempeh are great higher protein, lower carb plant-based options.

title: Diet Variety
body:
Things to take into consideration: Diet variety

If you’re eating to manage insulin resistance and are plant-based you are going to likely end up with a very short list of foods you can eat (no meat, poultry, seafood, potentially dairy, as well as grains/cereals, starchy carbohydrates and sweeteners at certain meals).

This could cause you a lot of stress and/or promote disordered eating behaviors due to the restrictive nature.

title: Some questions to ask yourself
body:
If you’re struggling to know what to do in this situation, we have some thought-provoking questions for you:

  • How is this way of eating potentially impacting my root cause?


  • How is this way of eating helping or hindering my ability to achieve my health goals?


  • Is there a way I could blend both dietary approaches together to achieve my health goals?(ie. introducing one or a couple of animal food sources like eggs / seafood?)


  • Should I decide to incorporate some animal sources back into my diet, what will make this transition easier for me to mentally adjust to?(ie. choosing only grass-fed/organic/wild-caught sources and/or only buying locally sourced options and/or only incorporating one new animal source at a time).


  • What’s holding me back from changing? How can I address this?


  • Can I achieve a very similar outcome to what I'm trying to achieve by just being a little bit more flexible rather than saying I'm either eating all animal proteins or I'm eating none of them? (ie. including free range eggs)

title: Nutrients
body:
There are a number of really key nutrients that are either only available in animal sources, or are extremely hard for our bodies to absorb enough, or convert to the usable form, to avoid deficiency or low levels of. This can stop our bodies from functioning optimally, and contribute to our PCOS symptoms.

We highly recommend booking a consult with an expert to help you formulate a plan to make this program work for you on a vegetarian, vegan or plant-based diet, to ensure your nutrient levels are considered.

title: What are the key changes we have made?
body:
1. Consuming 40-50g of protein at breakfast

  2. Reducing carbohydrates at breakfast to a minimal amount

  3. Ideally eating within 1 hour of waking

As well as:

  • Adding in as many non-starchy vegetables when you can

  • Incorporating some healthy fats

title: Protein Goal
body:
To help manage the increase in protein at breakfast:

  • Build up to the protein goal gradually

  • Mix and match protein sources (e.g. eggs + salmon, protein powder + eggs)

  • Opt for whole food proteins where you can

  • Utilize protein powder to support protein goal

title: Breakfast Builder
body: Remember to use this super handy guide to create your breakfast.

title: Mind as a Problem Solving Machine
body: ADD

title: Wondering what to do about dairy?
body:
Whilst not everyone who has PCOS needs to go dairy free, due to your root cause we do suggest you try to reduce your dairy intake, particularly for certain types of dairy.

Dairy has a significant amount of a compound called insulin like growth factor (IGF) and branched chain amino acids - both of which can be very insulin stimulating.

As we’re working on your insulin resistance as the root cause of your PCOS symptoms, we’re trying to reduce your insulin response.

Research has looked into the insulin effect of certain foods, and this showed that dairy elicits a particularly large insulin response. Some dairy foods caused a significantly greater response than others - namely low-fat fruit yogurt, more so than even white bread! Surprising right?!

So while you don’t need to go totally dairy free, we’d recommend following these guidelines:
summary:
Effect on insulin:

Higher (avoid/reduce): Milk, yogurt (particularly low fat dairy), whey protein powder, and soft cheeses such as brie, ricotta and cottage cheese.

Lower (okay in small quantities): Hard cheese, butter and higher fat dairy.

Example: A splash of milk in your tea won’t have much of an impact, but 250mL in your smoothie will.

title: All About Lunch and Dinner
body:
We’re going to be tweaking your lunch and dinner to better manage your insulin.

You can tweak your favourite recipes to suit, or build your own lunch or dinner bowl following our handy meal builder guide (at the end of this lesson).

We’ve broken it down into four main sections so you can mix and match to create a well rounded, balanced meal without having to follow a strict meal plan.

The four main sections are:
Non-starchy vegetables
Complex carb
Protein
Fat

title: Non-starchy vegetables
body:
Quantity: Include 3 or more non-starchy vegetables in each meal.

You want to aim for about ⅔ of your plate as non-starchy vegetables. Before you think “Oh man, ⅔ of my plate is boring, sad vegetables”, know that it doesn’t have to be just plain boiled broccoli!

Non-starchy vegetables tend to be less insulin-stimulating because they’re not as carbohydrate heavy as starchy vegetables. They’re also packed with goodness like vitamins, minerals, antioxidants and fiber.

Top tip: If you’re struggling to figure out whether something is starchy or non-starchy, simply Google "is X a non-starchy vegetable?".

title: Complex Carbohydrate
body:
Quantity: Include 1 ‘complex’ carbohydrate in each meal.

This includes starchy vegetables, whole grains, legumes and fruit.

These foods contain more carbohydrates and are more insulin stimulating, so one serving is manageable for our insulin.

Top Tip: You can also mix and match. You may want to have an apple for dessert and have some quinoa with your dinner. In this situation, you can simply enjoy half of each serving portion in the meal builder.

title: Protein
body:
Quantity: Include 1 source of protein in each meal.

We know protein is important for satiety, as well as keeping our bodies strong and functioning well.

In the meal builder guide, we've given each protein source a varying weight for the portion size.

These amounts are based on the current insulin demand research.

title: Fats
body:
Quantity: Include 1 source of fat in each meal.

Fats are important for a range of body functions, including helping manage our insulin. Fats are very satiating, particularly when in the solid form (nuts, seeds, avocados for example).

We don’t want to focus on calories, but it is important to note that fats are far more calorically dense than protein or carbohydrates.

For this reason, portion sizes of fat sources are much smaller than for protein and carbs.

This is important as we don’t want you to unknowingly end up eating a lot more dietary fat thinking that it’s calorically equivalent, then feel like you’re gaining weight and that these changes ‘aren’t working’.

Top Tip: If you’re someone who gets hungry between meals we suggest opting for solid forms of fats like nuts seeds and avocado as opposed to oils to keep you fuller for longer.

title: A Balanced Plate & Salad Guide
Mindful Eating
body:
Eating mindfully can be really damn hard!

A lot of us aren’t used to being completely distraction free when we’re eating. We’ve gotten so used to consuming other content like social media or TV while we consume our food.

Mindful eating means to be fully present when eating your meal, engaging with the food, and the person/people you’re sharing the meal with.

The practice of eating mindfully helps us to slow down the rate at which we eat, and better tune in to our hunger and fullness cues and ease bloating and digestive issues.

This is particularly important if we’ve been dieting chronically, as over time this can really disrupt our bodies hunger signaling.

title: Our top tips for mindful eating
body:
We’ve got 4 tips to help you eat more mindfully:


1. Make sure that you don’t do anything else while you eat

No driving, working, browsing on instagram or watching TV! Nothing other than talking with people that you're eating with.

You might need to leave home 5 minutes earlier so you can have breakfast at work rather than while you’re driving, or take your lunch away from your desk rather than eating it in front of your computer.

It may feel a bit weird initially because you’re used to multitasking while you quickly get a meal in, but keep pushing with it.

title: Our top tips for mindful eating
body:
2. Focus on all 5 of your senses while you eat

Listen to how the food crunches when you pick it up, the colours, the textures in your mouth, the smells. Really taste the food - this sounds simple, but it's amazing how little people really stop to notice the flavors of their food!


A little fun: This is a great technique to involve children in if you have them, making mindful eating a habit for the whole household.

title: Our top tips for mindful eating
body:
3. Take your time!

Put your fork down after each mouthful. Use this time to really taste the food, and between bites chat to the people you’re eating with.

Longer meal times allow your stomach to send signals to your brain telling it when you're full and satisfied, meaning you’re less likely to over-stuff yourself.

title: Our top tips for mindful eating
body:
4. Eat off a plate!

Aim to put everything you eat on a plate (where it makes sense to) and preferably eat with a knife and fork.

Even if you’re having something like a piece of chocolate, put it on a plate, sit down and practice your mindfulness techniques. Really savor that piece of chocolate.

What you'll likely find is that if you just wolf it down and pretend it didn't happen, you're more likely to go back for more. Whereas if you sit down and mindfully eat it, you're more likely to feel like just that one piece was satisfying enough.

title: The Hunger Satiety Scale
summary:
Audio Summary:

  • Society (through diet culture, traditional etiquette and a variety of other factors) has moved us away from listening to our innate food signalling system - our hunger and fullness cues.

  • We recommend trying to use the hunger satiety scale at least once a day (at your leisure - work or schedules might not work well with this at all times), with the hope that you’ll get better in touch with your hunger and satiety signals.

title: The Aim:
body: 4-6: Ideally our hunger would stay within the green zone.

title: Start eating:
body: 3-4: Start eating when you dip into this zone
summary:
1-2: try to avoid this level of hunger.



If our blood sugar levels get too low it can start to affect us on a deeper hormonal level such as our body's stress signals. It can also make it very hard to determine when you are satisfied when you do eat, meaning you’re more likely to overeat.

Top Tip: It’s good initially to keep high protein snacks available to try keep you from getting to a 1-2, especially initially whilst you navigate your meal changes.

title: Stop eating:
body: 6: This is a good level to stop eating.
summary:
This is where you feel full but not overstuffed, where you start thinking “I'm not hungry anymore. I'm feeling quite satisfied”.

It takes about 20 minutes for your body to register that you’re full. So if you stop eating at a 6, you’ll often find that you’re full soon after.

title: Top Tip: The Saved Plate Technique
body:
We often find people worry that they’ll be hungry later if they stop eating at 6.

This is where we incorporate the ‘Saved Plate’ technique so you have that ‘security blanket’ of food you can go back to if you need it.

The goal is to only eat until you are a 6 on the scale. If you still have food on your plate, at this point we want you to pop this in the fridge and go away for 20 minutes. If your hunger quickly returns after 20 minutes, you can then go back and finish the rest.

Because you're not wasting the food, you're just putting it away for later in case you need it, it helps remove the guilt of needing to finish everything on your plate. You can always eat it at your next meal, or finish it as a snack later on. It is a great technique to use while you learn how much food is a good amount to serve yourself.


Top Tip: If you’re eating out you can use this same technique and ask for a takeaway container when you reach your 6. Then you know that if you’re still hungry you can eat some more later, or have a delicious lunch for tomorrow.

title: page 1
body:
You’re not alone in using food as a reward, and it’s not your fault you’ve established this system!


Why is that?


1. We need food to survive, so our brains are already wired to have a reward circuitry for eating foods, particularly high energy and fast delivering fuels, like fats and sugar.

2. Over time we're conditioned to believe that ‘treat’ foods have positive connotations or emotions that come with them, which over time creates a  reward circuitry in our brains.

title: page 2
body:
What can we do to change this?


We can use mindfulness as a tool to tap into our reward-based learning process and rewire old habits to new habits that better serve us.

This might be changing a food reward to an activity reward, or a food that better serves our health.

For example:

title: Intro
body:
As we’ve asked you to reduce your sugar intake on this program you may still find yourself wanting or even craving sugar from time to time.

While we’ve meticulously refined the program to try and preempt sugar cravings through keeping your blood sugar stable, there will still be times when you just want it.

This is because sugar activates the pleasure and reward parts of our brain, and for most of us, is intimately linked to celebrations, commiserations and everything in between.

So, you’ll need to have some strategies in place to deal with this!

title: Our top 12 tips for dealing with sugar cravings:
body:
1. Keep sugar as an ‘outside the house treat’

We only have so much willpower to say ‘no’ to foods that we love, but that aren’t necessarily great for our body.

So if these foods are staring us in the face every time we open the cupboard, we’re only going to be able to say ‘no’ so many times before we cave (no matter how great our self control!) - so don’t do this to yourself!

Make your home sugar-free and save up your restraint for outside the home.

If you live with a partner, family or flat, explain to them what you’re doing and that sugar is going to be too tempting for you. You could ask them to eat or store any sweets out of the house (or at least kitchen) to keep the environment sugar-free.  



2. Avoid blood sugar crashes 

Blood sugar crashes not only drive sugar cravings but intense hunger (those dreaded hanger attacks!) and leave you feeling shaky, jittery, irritable, faint and unable to concentrate.

Eating meals that support a stable blood sugar level is key.

This means balanced meals with decent amounts of protein and healthy fats, and ideally very low sugars.

title: Our top 12 tips for dealing with sugar cravings:
body:
3. Eat 40-50g protein for breakfast

Breakfast is the MOST important meal for setting us up for stable blood sugar throughout the day and protein is our best tool to support this.

Protein helps to stop your blood sugar from going up and down like a roller coaster to avoid blood those dreaded crashes where sugar cravings ensue.  


4. Avoid sugar at breakfast

Seeing as breakfast is key for establishing our blood sugar levels for the day, avoiding sugar entirely at breakfast sets us up with the best chance to avoid any blood sugar crashes and cravings.

Even if you’re having pancakes for breakfast as a treat, try and opt for an alternative topping or sugar substitute syrup so that your blood sugar doesn’t come crashing down later in the morning.

title: Our top 12 tips for dealing with sugar cravings:
body:
5. Have a savory breakfast

We have found that those who start the day with a ‘sweet’ tasting (even if it’s low sugar) rather than savory breakfast are more likely to have sugar cravings.

It’s not the case for everyone, but if you’re a sweet breakfast person, give this technique a try for at least one week and see if you notice a difference.


6. Recognize your craving patterns

Know what times of the day you tend to crave things and put strategies in place for these.

Often cravings can be out of habit - your palette is used to finishing dinner with dessert or having a biscuit with a cup of tea.

If you tend to have mid-afternoon sweet cravings at work, organize meetings in the afternoon to keep yourself occupied and stop you from hitting the vending machine, or if it’s after dinner, establish an enjoyable evening routine like having a bath, going for a walk or listening to an audiobook.

These need to be activities that will take your mind off sweets and keep the cravings at bay, and be prepared to do them a lot!

title: Our top 12 tips for dealing with sugar cravings:
body:
7. Know your emotional triggers 

Most of us will turn to food for comfort when our emotions are triggered.

Whether it’s for a positive emotion such as a reward or celebration or from a painful emotion such as stress, hurt, rejection or the most common one - boredom.

Recognizing if and when we look to sugar for that positive dopamine hit or ‘to make things better’ is a key way to avoid the tailspin that is emotional eating.

Use the Tuna Test to help you establish if you are eating for hunger or not.

8. Eat mindfully

Do you find yourself thinking about what your next treat might be before you’ve even finished your dinner? Mindful eating helps our brain to register that we’re fueling it, to help regulate our hunger and satiety hormones better.

title: Our top 12 tips for dealing with sugar cravings:
body:
9. Sleep is key

Studies have shown that just one night of less than 5 hours sleep can lead to insulin resistance and that it makes us crave simple carbohydrates.

Lack of sleep can also affect our emotional stability, making us more susceptible to emotional triggers.

So, getting plenty of sleep is key! (We’ll come back to sleep in a later module!).


10. Be prepared

We find we’re much more likely to eat whatever we can get our hands on when we’re really hungry. Being prepared is key to ensuring you have food on hand that supports your insulin and blood sugars.
  • Meal preparation is key for when you’re out and about
  • Emergency healthy snacks on hand to stop you from stopping past the convenience store where sweet temptation is wrought
  • Do a fridge and pantry cleanup. If it’s not in the house, you can’t be tempted by it
  • Don’t go to the grocery store hungry, as this will not only result in you buying something sweet, but likely alter your trolley contents too

title: Our top 12 tips for dealing with sugar cravings:
body:
11. Smart Snacking

When a sugar craving comes on, rather than looking for a snack that is exactly that (sugar or simple carbs), look for a snack that contains reasonable amounts of healthy fats and protein.

Why?

1. Protein and fats both blunt the insulin response, so if your snack contains some carbs having some protein and fats will help to keep your blood sugar more stable, to help reduce further blood sugar crashes.

2. Protein and fats also keep you fuller for longer than simple carbs and sugars, which helps avoid further cravings.
  • Celery sticks with peanut butter
  • Carrot sticks with hummus or almond butter
  • Boiled egg
  • Guacamole with nut/seed-based crackers

title: Our top 12 tips for dealing with sugar cravings:
body:
12. Have alternative ‘treats’
 
We know that sometimes that no amount of peanut butter will curb the sugar cravings.

Sometimes only sugar will hit the spot, and overeating on another snack only to end up eating sugar as well isn’t the best method.

In these cases we recommend having some healthier treats on hand so that you can still get a sugar fix, but to a lesser extent than could be otherwise, and potentially with a side of fats and protein also.

If you’re also used to having a chocolate biscuit with your cup of tea after dinner, it can be a hard habit for your palette to break. So instead, how about having one of these sweet tasting alternatives, that will curb the craving but not spike your blood sugar.
  • Dark chocolate: 85% or higher is best, but if you can’t stomach that just yet, start with 70% and build up
  • Stevia sweetened milk chocolate: there are many great alternatively sweetened chocolates on the market now
  • Homemade treats: A piece of your favorite baking made with one of the sugar substitutes like erythritol

title: What does sugar mean for me?
summary:
Audio summary
  • Having insulin resistance means that the insulin in our bodies is no longer as good at processing sugar, meaning the sugar sits in our bloodstream for a lot longer than it should.

  • If we keep up a high sugar intake, we can further reduce the ability of our insulin to function properly, and this increases the amount of insulin our body produces. Our bodies think that throwing more insulin at the problem might help clear up the sugar.

  • But it’s this increased insulin that’s one of the main drivers for our PCOS symptoms.

  • We have the power to make our bodies more sensitive to insulin so our body doesn’t need to produce as much, through our lifestyle and diet (that we maintain for the majority of the time!).

  • Maintaining a stable blood sugar level helps to keep the demand on our insulin under control, and save our bodies from firing out more insulin.

  • Minimizing foods that deliver large amounts of simple sugars (these ones are absorbed into our bloodstream really quickly and cause a big spike in insulin) is key to maintaining steady insulin levels.

title: Simple Sugars
body:
Simple sugars (the ones we want to avoid most of the time)

These include:
  • Sugar (and all its derivatives e.g. brown, white, demuera)  

  • Sugar syrups e.g. honey, agave, maple, glucose syrup, fructose syrup, brown rice syrup, malt syrup, molasses 

  • High GI carbohydrates e.g. white bread, breakfast cereals, pastas, ripe bananas

  • Foods where sugar is predominant ingredient e.g. soft drinks and sodas, candy, chocolate bars, baking, desserts, highly processed foods such as cooking sauces

title: Sugar Alternatives
body:
This doesn’t mean that you can never have sugar again!

But, instead try to keep this to once or twice a week or use one of the sugar alternatives.

To make things easier, we’ve got a handy list of our favorite sugar alternatives to substitute sugar with, and how to know what and when to use each type.

title: Natural Sweeteners
body:
Best: Plant-based natural sweeteners

The best sweeteners to choose are the following plant-based sweeteners as these have been found to have no effect on insulin.

These include:
  • Stevia
  • Monk Fruit
  • Thaumatin

Top tip: These are highly concentrated sweeteners (up to 2000x sweeter than sugar), so you only need a tiny amount to give you the sweetness you need.

title: Sugar Alcohols
body:
Fine to use: Sugar Alcohols

Sugar alcohols are a category of sweet carbohydrates found naturally (aim for these where possible), or processed from other sugars, but these also don’t raise insulin levels (they still have calories and carbohydrates however).

These include:
  • Erythritol, glycerol, lactitol, maltitol, mannitol, sorbitol, xylitol . . if it ends with ‘itol’ it’s likely a sugar alcohol
  • Isomalt
  • Allulose
  • Hydrogenated starch hydrolysates (HSH)

Sugar alcohols have the same sweetness as normal table sugar and so are best used in baking, where you need the same properties as sugar.

Top tip: excess consumption can cause bloating and other digestive discomfort.

title: Artificial Sweeteners
body:
Occasional: Artificial sweeteners

Artificial sweeteners are typically found in diet soft drinks or sugar-free sweets and should be considered a ‘sometimes’ food, as emerging research suggests that a consistent consumption of these has been linked to poor health effects.

As the research is only emerging, we’re simply being cautious and recommending the other sweeteners as better options to have most of the time. These include:

  • Sucralose (Splenda)
  • Aspartame (Equal, Nutrasweet)
  • Saccharin (Sweet'N Low, Sugar Twin)
  • Acesulfame K (Sunett)

title: Meal Planning
summary:
Audio summary:
  • Meal planning is a great tool to help you make one of the biggest habit changes you can make: changing the way you eat

  • Pick a way to meal plan that suits your lifestyle e.g. for the whole week or just a few days ahead

title: Meal Planning
body:
How to meal plan:

1. Set a time to plan. It might seem straight forward, but set yourself a time in the day to do this - if you’re doing a weekly plan this might be on Sunday, before you go to the supermarket. You’ll be surprised at how many people run out of time and end up at the supermarket again with no clear plan for the week ahead. 

2. Plan Plan Plan! Sit down and plan out what meals you’ll be having for breakfast, lunch and dinner for the week. If you enjoy doing some meal prepping in the week, ensure to plan these meals into your week. Then have a think about snacks too. We’ve got a super handy downloadable planner here.

3. Ingredients list: Distill all the ingredients you will need to make these meals and write these on your list.

Top Tip! Plan your supermarket trip so that you have time to get any meal prep done for the week ahead. This might look like a Sunday early afternoon shop so that (before you put all of your groceries away) you can spend the afternoon getting a little meal prepping sorted for the week.

title: Meal Planning
body:
2 different methods for meal planning:
  • The 3-4 week meal plan: 
3 or 4 weeks of planned meals that rotate indefinitely (of course you can always swap a recipe out eventually!)

  • Flavors method:
Have 3-4 nights of the week that are simple protein + carb + veg meals that you can add an assortment of homemade sauces or marinades too to boost the flavor.
Use the other nights of the week for more recipe or dish style meals.

title: Meal Prep
summary:
Meal Prepping

Rather than laboring away making all your meals for the week ahead . . .

we think simply making a few of the key (time-consuming) elements

on a Sunday (for example) for the week ahead can make for much more meal enjoyment through the week


Some ideas are:
  • Roasting or boiling root vegetables

  • Grating cauliflower rice and freezing it in portion sizes

  • Making a batch of bacon and egg ‘muffins’ or a frittata for breakfasts

  • Roasting a chicken for salads

  • Making seeded crackers or tortillas

  • Making a healthier treat for when those sugar cravings come in

title: Handy Hack
body:
Meal Planning Hack

Plan your supermarket trip so that you have time to get any meal prep done for the week ahead.

This might look like a Sunday early afternoon shop so that (before you put all of your groceries away) you can spend the afternoon getting a little meal prepping sorted for the week.

title: Why are they so important?
body:
Increasing non-starchy veggie is important for a number of reasons including:
  • Satiety!

  • Nutrients! Particularly vitamins, minerals, antioxidants like phytonutrients and fiber.

  • Food Variety! It’s nice to focus on adding something IN to your meals rather than feeling like you’re cutting out everything!

1 serving is approximately a fist size of leafy green vegetables or a cupped handful of other non-starchy veggies.

title: Tips to increase your veggies!
body:
Here’s some handy and easy ideas to help you ramp up your non-starchy vegetable intake! 


1. Keep veggies in your fridge for all meals of the day 

Here’s some examples:
  • Snacks - easy to cut up or bite-sized! Carrots, cucumber, bell peppers (capsicums), celery (these go great with dips like a guacamole!) or cherry tomatoes  

  • Breakfast - leafy greens like kale, arugula or spinach, or tomatoes, zucchini or mushrooms

  • Lunch - no-cook veggies can be helpful! Salad greens, cabbage, carrots, sprouts, tomatoes, cucumber or capsicums

  • Dinner - the skies the limit with how much and what kind of veg you can pack in here!

Top Tip: Don’t throw away half used veggies! There’s always somewhere that half of a zucchini can go into!

title: Tips to increase your veggies!
body:
2. Plan to prepare meals that are great for adding in plenty of veggies


Stir-fry: Almost any non-starchy veg can work in a stir-fry, and is perfect for using up leftover veg

Frittata / Loaded Omelette: Another easy breakfast, lunch or light dinner option to crowd out with vegetables (especially leftover ones!)

Smoothie: Green smoothies are great for this! Frozen zucchini is also a great swap for frozen bananas

Salads: By nature, salads are really easy to pack with lots of vegetables!

Tomato based sauces (e.g. shakshuka, bolognese, ragu, chilli, casseroles): A great option if you find you need plenty of sauce and/or cooking to get your vegetables down. We love to add grated zucchini and carrots into the tomato sauce

Curries: Zucchini, carrots, leafy or Asian greens such as bok choy, green beans, broccoli or cauliflower work in a curry, and they are great to use up leftover veg!

title: Tips to increase your veggies!
body:
3. Aim to buy local and seasonal

Buying local and seasonal non-starchy vegetables is a great hack as they’re often much more fresh and much cheaper than getting imported or out of season produce.

They're typically much more flavorful too!

Top tip: You can also incorporate snap frozen vegetables if that makes this easier for you, these are just as nutritious as their fresh counterparts!

title: An example day
body:
An example day with 10 servings:


Breakfast: Smoothie with berries, frozen zucchini, spinach, protein powder and almond milk (+3 serves)

Lunch: Caesar salad with chicken, boiled eggs, romaine lettuce and dressing (+1 serve)

Snack: Carrot with homemade dip (+1 serve)

Dinner: Coconut chickpea curry with onion, diced tomatoes, capsicum, spinach on a bed of cauliflower rice (or mix of cauliflower rice and brown rice) (+5 serves)

Done!

title: Add a pinch of inspiration!
body:
If you’re not a fan of vegetables then increasing your intake significantly can seem overwhelming.

But, we don’t want you to think these have to be plain, boiled veggies (eww no thanks!) - we want to help you introduce you to new ways of preparing vegetables that might just make you fall in love with them!  

Top Tips:

  • Season season season! Herbs, spices and oils are your friend! A little salt and pepper can go a long way too!

  • Flavorful ingredients: Look at incorporating ingredients toasted nuts and seeds and aromatics like ginger, garlic or chilli (we love chilli flakes!)

  • Expand your cooking repertoire: have a look through cookbooks, Pinterest or food instagrams for inspiration

  • Play with flavors from your favorite cuisine: find out what herbs and spices different cuisines use and pair those with their commonly used veggies such as Italian with basil, garlic and tomatoes, or Indian with curry powder, coriander seeds and cauliflower!

title: Add a dash of punchy flavor!
body:
Here are some of our favorite ways to spice up our veggies:

  • Sautéing spinach and/or mushroom in avocado oil with oregano, basil or thyme

  • Citrus + herbs! Toss lime juice and fresh coriander through a slaw or lemon and basil through a salad

  • Chilli! Chilli flakes, chilli oil, chilli crunch - we love a good bit of heat!

  • Toasted seeds make for great salad sprinkles! Toast seeds with soy sauce in a pan for tamari flavored seeds

  • Roasting veggies (such as pumpkin, cauliflower, broccoli, carrot, capsicums or zucchini) with the following spice combinations:

    • Moroccan-inspired: cumin, coriander and paprika

    • Indian-inspired: turmeric, coriander and ginger

    • Mexican-inspired: smoked paprika, coriander and garlic salt

    • Italian-inspired: Lemon pepper, thyme and oregano

    • French-inspired: marjoram, rosemary, tarragon and thyme


  • Roasted nuts! Add walnuts, almonds or cashews to the veggie roasting tray for the last 5 minutes of cook time to add more flavor (and nutrients!)

title: To snack, or not to snack
summary:
Audio Summary:


  • There aren’t any specific meal times - you are the only person who will know your hunger cues for meals (although we do recommend breakfast within 1 hour of waking)

  • There aren’t any specific amount of snacks you should eat - again this comes down to your hunger, or other factors like how you structure your day

  • For the majority of the time, we want to use snacks to avoid crippling hunger between meals, rather than eating them for emotional reasons or boredom

  • Use the hunger satiety scale or the tuna test (coming up in this lesson!) to help you decide whether you need a snack or not

title: Handy tool: The Tuna Test
body:
Struggling to decipher what’s a passing craving and what’s an actual hunger pang? Try this little trick (and yes, there’s a plant-based option too!).

All you need to do is pick a food that's not particularly palatable for you e.g. a can of tuna - edible and nutritious but not particularly something that you'd crave.

When you start to feel hungry, go grab that plain can of tuna (or your equivalent, e.g. a can of chickpeas).

If your immediate reaction is “nope - I’m not desperate enough to have that”  then you’ll get a good gauge on your physical hunger level, and you’ll be able to make a mindful decision around when to have your next meal or snack.


Why tuna?

A lot of people look to nuts as a ‘back-up’ snack to have on hand (e.g. a handbag, desk drawer or car snack) however we often find that as they can be quite moreish, you can end up eating them whether you're hungry or not.

If you find you do dip into your 'back up snack' often, try swapping it out for a can of tuna.

title: Snacks recommendations
body:
‘Snack foods’ have gotten a bad name for themselves as they are typically associated with convenience foods (pretty highly processed foods). These convenience foods are processed to have a longer shelf life, but in the processing often a lot of the nutrients are stripped from the foods, and they’ve normally been dehydrated to some extent. They’ve often had a fair bit of sugar and salt added to them. Because of this, they’re much less filling (and nutritious) and they’re often very moreish (well done snack companies!) than fresh, whole foods.

So if not ‘snack foods’, what should I snack on? 

Fresh whole foods, or minimally processed foods are the best foods to snack on. They also tend to be more insulin-friendly and much lower in sugar. We know that healthy snacks can be a real pain point, so we’ve made a big list to inspire your snack game!

title: Expectations & weekly wins
body:
“When can I expect to see changes?” - this is a common question.

We’re going to look at a tool to help you with recognizing the progress you’re making, all of the ‘towards moves’, no matter how small.
We call these our weekly wins, which help keep things in perspective, see all the steps you are taking in the right direction, and manage our expectations.

Audio Summary:
  • Think of your symptoms as a product of your root cause of PCOS. PCOS symptoms will have taken time to develop from the hormonal imbalance to visible symptoms, thus reversing these symptoms will take time also. 
  • The choices and changes we’ll make in this program can not only help our PCOS symptoms, but provide life-long change for our health
  • Focus on the ‘towards moves’ and changes that are within your control, rather than waiting for symptoms to change. Remember: We may not get that instant gratification, but our future selves thank us for making them.
  • Instead, focus on your weekly wins, the small successes, all the towards moves you’ve made and celebrate these milestones
  • We’ll be checking in at the end of each week to hear about your weekly wins

title: Expectations & weekly wins
body:
Weekly wins examples:
  • ‘I completed my 3 planned exercise sessions this week’
  • ‘Four of my breakfasts met the guidelines this week and I noticed that I wasn’t as hungry’
  • ‘I put my phone away before bed and read a book instead and really enjoyed it - plus I felt more rested’

If you find this hard, break it down and you can think of:
  • What towards moves have I made this week?
  • What values and goals were those towards moves guided by?
  • What away moves have I made this week?
  • What were the function of these away move

title: The importance of sleep
summary:
Audio Summary:
  • Sleep tends to be dropped off the priority list when we’re time-poor or stressed

  • But, quality sleep and recovery are a major pillar of our overall health and well-being

Did you know?

In the 1980s a study was conducted where they deprived rats of sleep or food until they died. What they found was that the rats died 20% sooner from sleep deprivation than they did from starvation. This shows you just how important sleep is for us to function properly.  


When it comes to your PCOS, here’s why it’s so important:

title: Sleep & Insulin
body:
Sleep is particularly important in insulin activity,  where not getting enough sleep actually reduces our cells’ sensitivity to insulin, making them more resistant to insulin.


Research has shown us that getting just 4-5 hours sleep a night for 2 weeks, reduces our insulin sensitivity by 50%.


This means that previously very healthy people with no insulin resistance, could be diagnosed as pre diabetic after just 2 weeks of sleep deprivation.

title: Sleep & Sugar Cravings
body:
Sleep deprivation makes us crave sugar.

Research shows that when we’re lacking sleep, the area of our brain that is responsible for self control is inhibited and the areas controlling pleasure and desire are activated.

This makes us crave foods, like sugar and simple carbohydrates that give us an instant pleasure hit, and restrict our ability to have any self control.

When sugar cravings are already something we struggle with, lack of sleep can compound that and send us on a blood sugar roller coaster.

We’re also more likely to be hungry all the time, to eat more and to be less motivated to exercise.

title: How much sleep should we be aiming for?
body:
Like most things, there’s no “one amount fits all” when it comes to sleep.

Adequate sleep means you’re waking up feeling refreshed, preferably a bit before your alarm.

For almost all people it’s usually between 7-9 hours.

This can change depending on what else is going on in your week at that time. You might find that you feel best at the higher end of this range.


Did you know?

You have a higher chance of being hit by lightning than having the gene that means you can function off only 5 hours sleep.

For more info on this, read "Why We Sleep" by Dr Matthew Walker.

title: Booster
9 Tips For a Better Sleep
body:
Dr Matthew Walker, our go-to sleep expert has some fantastic tips for better sleep. Focusing on our ‘sleep hygiene’ is important to set us up for success in sleep.

9 tips for a better sleep:


1. Regularity:

Aim to get your body into a routine of sleeping and waking at the same time - yes, even on the weekends.

2. Light:

Darkness helps signal to our body that it's time to wind down and produce melatonin to help us get to sleep, just as lightness in the morning helps signal to our body to wake.
We are a dark-deprived society with technology so actively darkening your environment is important.

title: 9 Tips For a Better Sleep
body:
3. Temperature:

You need to get cool to get to sleep - roughly 68°F/18.5°C is optimal.
Having a hot shower within the hour before bed will help by bringing your body temperature up and then back down before you sleep.


4. “Walk it out”:

If you’ve been awake for 20 minutes, then get up, go and do something else and only come back to bed when you’re sleepy.
Lying awake in bed builds a learned association that you're awake when you’re in bed. 

5. Alcohol & caffeine:

Avoid these near bed time.
Alcohol reduces REM sleep, so while the sedative effects of alcohol will help you get to sleep 'quickly', the quality of your sleep will be affected.
Caffeine is a stimulant, it blocks sleep-inducing chemicals in the brain and increases adrenaline production.

title: 9 Tips For a Better Sleep
body:
6. Remove technology from the bedroom, for two reasons:

- Anticipation anxiety:
Don’t make checking your phone (e.g., emails, texts, etc.) the first thing you do in the morning as this trains your brain that even as you're tucking yourself in bed at night to expect that anxiety waiting for you on your side table.

This “anticipatory anxiety” actually lightens your sleep throughout the night because of that expectation.

- “Sleep procrastination”:

i.e. scrolling through your phone looking for that next interesting thing and procrastinating the process of putting your mind to rest.

Procrastination hack from Matthew Walker’s colleague, Michael Grandner: If you’re going to have your phone in your bedroom, make it a rule that you can only use it if you’re standing up.

After 5-10 minutes of standing you just think, “God, I just want to sit down. I just want to get into bed.”

title: 9 Tips For a Better Sleep
body:
7. Keep the bed for sleep and sex:

These two things are all we want to associate our bed with rather than paying bills, reading emails, watching netflix etc.

8. Wind-down routine:

This is absolutely critical to build it into your routine. Many people expect sleep to be like a light switch — it’s just not like that.
A routine might be 15 minutes for some, others it’s 30minutes. Things like light stretches, meditation, putting all screens away, showering, drinking tea and reading can be a part of the routine.


9. Keep a pen and paper by your bed:

If a thought you’ve just had is playing over in your head as you need to remember it, jotting it down will help remove the stress of forgetting.

title: Sleep Hygeine
body:
There’s lots we can do to create a better sleep environment through the sleep hygiene tips we looked at in yesterday's lesson. Some of these sound simple, or silly, but they can make a huge impact on your quality of sleep.

In today’s lesson we want you to focus on implementing one of these sleep hygiene tips, and putting it into practice for the week.

title: Sleep Aids
body:
Silicone Earplugs

Silicone earplugs cover the ear cavity, rather than going into the ear canal.

The benefit is that they are great at reducing background noise (like snoring or plane noise), but don’t damage the ear canal.


Blue Light Blockers

These can help to block the blue light from devices that disrupt our circadian rhythm. Using from midday onwards can help improve sleep.

You can purchase glasses that have blue light blocking lenses (even if you don’t need opticals).

Technology such as laptops, phones and tablets can have blue light blocker filters added (some apple products have built in, others require an app to be downloaded).

title: Sleep Aids
body:
Silk Eye Mask

An eye mask helps reduce the effect light can have on interrupting your sleep.

These are particularly good for when visiting friends and family, staying in hotels, or on planes.


Sunrise Alarm

A sunrise alarm is a gentler way to wake, as it simulates the gradual lightening of the room just as the morning sun would, meaning your body naturally wakes due to the light stimulation.

The difference is you can choose the time at which you rise.

This, paired with more dim lighting and no white lights before bed can help your melatonin and cortisol (sleep and wake hormones) to get back into rhythm.

title: Sleep Aids
body:
Sleep Tracking Software

For anyone who is a tech buff or loves data, there are plenty of softwares that can track your heart rate and sleep cycles, such as your REM and non-REM sleep states.

Oura rings, Fitbit, Whoop are all softwares that have this functionality.


Weighted Blankets

The research is very limited, however many people find having a weighted blanket can help with getting to sleep, and achieving a deeper sleep.

title: Problem #1 - "I’m tired but wired”
summary:
Audio Summary:

Some remedies to help you wind down and get sleepy, and improve your sleep quality:

  • Work on reducing your stress levels

  • Practicing deep breathing

  • Ditch the caffeine

  • Give meditating a go!

  • Implement a sleep routine

title: Problem #2 - “I wake during the night”
summary:
Audio Summary

Some remedies to help you wind down and get sleepy, and improve your sleep quality:
  • Have a savoury snack before bed, or keep one on your bedside table

  • Work on reducing your stress levels

  • Practicing deep breathing

  • Ditch the caffeine

  • Give meditating a go!

  • Implement a sleep routine

title: Problem #3 - “I wake up feeling tired”
summary:
Audio Summary:


There are a few different reasons for why this might be, so here are some remedies to help you improve your sleep quality:

  • Make sure you’re getting enough hours of sleep every night - at least 7 hours but ideally 8 or 9 hours

  • Be aware of the alcohol effect  

  • Keep the room temperature cool - 68°F/18.5°C is optimal

  • Ditch the caffeine

  • Aim to rebalance your stress hormones

  • Work on reducing your stress levels

  • Liquorice root for a morning cortisol boost *


  • If all else isn’t working, do some testing to see if hypothyroidism or a vitamin deficiency is at play, such as iron or vitamin B12 causing you to feel exhausted

* Liquorice Root can help to boost cortisol. Taking 1000mg upon waking, then again mid morning, and again just after lunch. This may help reestablish your disrupted cortisol levels.

Note: Before purchasing or using any supplements - check with your doctor to ensure there are no contraindications and that these are right for you and your body.
Do not use when pregnant, breastfeeding, have high blood pressure or any other sodium/potassium concerns.

title: Additional Herbal Support
body:
If you identify with problems #1, #2 or #3, and all the initial lifestyle changes haven't helped, you can look into additional herbal support:

Herbal support can help your body to adapt to stress, or some supplements can aid better sleep.
  • Phosphatidylserine: take 4 capsules (400mg total) late in afternoon to help reduce cortisol level

  • Magnesium-Threonate: this is a special form of magnesium for sleep (to replace other magnesium supplements, not to be used in conjunction - take as per directed)
  • Melatonin: The ideal amount is different for all of us, but what you're aiming for is to take enough to help you sleep, but not so much that you wake really groggy.
    Start with 1 3mg capsule, but adjust upwards or down depending on your needs (so use less, pull the capsule apart and sprinkle ⅓-½ into some water).

Note: Before purchasing or using any supplements - check with your doctor to ensure there are no contraindications and that these are right for you and your body. Do not use when pregnant.

title: Problem #4 - “My sleeping problems happen the week before my period”
summary:
Audio Summary:

Some treatment options to help improve your sleep quality around your cycle:

For premenstrual insomnia: the most effective way to manage this is to treat your root cause, but of course, that won’t happen overnight. Micronised progesterone (which you will need to be prescribed by your doctor) has proven beneficial with helping premenstrual insomnia. Taking this cyclically can be effective.
  • Remove clock faces from the room to remove anxiety

  • Have a later bedtime to increase the pressure to sleep

  • “Walk it out”: If you’ve been awake for 20 minutes, then get up, go and do something else and only come back to bed when you’re sleepy. Lying awake in bed builds a learned association that you're awake when you’re in bed. As a consequence, you may only have a 6hr sleep window, but that six hours may be a very constant, solid sleep which is a better rest than lying in bed for 8 hours and tossing and turning for 2 hours.

  • Sleep Restriction Therapy

Iron deficiency: Treating your low iron should help both the symptoms of low iron AND the fatigue associated with both your cycle and the fatigue of deficiency in general. You’ll need to speak with your doctor about testing for an iron deficiency and supplementation to help reverse this.

title: Problem #5 - I struggle to get to sleep or stay asleep constantly
summary:
Audio Summary:

Some treatment options to help you get to sleep easier:

  • Remove clock faces from the room to remove anxiety

  • Have a later bedtime to increase the pressure to sleep

  • “Walk it out”: If you’ve been awake for 20 minutes, then get up, go and do something else and only come back to bed when you’re sleepy. Lying awake in bed builds a learned association that you're awake when you’re in bed. As a consequence, you may only have a 6hr sleep window, but that six hours may be a very constant, solid sleep which is a better rest than lying in bed for 8 hours and tossing and turning for 2 hours.

  • Speak to your doctor about your insomnia for a referral to a sleep specialist 

  • Look into sleep restriction therapy

title: Problem #6 - Sleep disrupted breathing
summary:
Audio Summary:
Did you know: up to 35% of people with PCOS may have Sleep Apnea - that’s up to 1 in 3 people with PCOS.

Those with PCOS driven by insulin resistance are up to 30x more likely to suffer from sleep disordered breathing. And, 80% of sleep apnea cases go undiagnosed which is concerning as it’s a serious health condition.

Symptoms of Sleep Apnea:
  • Excessive sleepiness during the day
  • Loud snoring 
  • If your partner tells you that you stop and start breathing during the night
  • Waking with a dry mouth
  • Morning headache
  • Find you wake up a lot during the night
  • Difficulty and lapses in concentration
  • Irritability
  • Weight gain
 
You don’t need to have all of these symptoms to be suffering from sleep apnea (you may not even snore). If you have any of these symptoms, talk to your doctor to get a referral to a sleep specialist. If you're in the US, you can find a board certified sleep specialist here.

"Do not leave sleep apnea untreated, it will shorten your lifespan, and it will certainly shorten your health span. That data is compelling.”- Matthew Walker, 'Why We Sleep'
 
Think this could be you?
See below a version of a common screening tool, The Epworth Sleepiness Score, used to diagnose sleep apnea. Use the questionnaire to self evaluate your sleep and if this is something you need to seek further medical help with. You can print off the PFD below and take it to your GP/health practitioner if you wish.

title: Sleep Apnea Questionaire
Caffeine & Sleep
summary:
Audio summary:

Caffeine:
  • Is a stimulant for our bodies

  • Stimulates our adrenal glands to produce more stress hormones

  • Blocks a neurotransmitter called adenosine (the one responsible for making us feel drowsy), but we can’t continuously block adenosine without any consequences. . .

  • Everyone’s ability to break down caffeine differs, as there’s two genes responsible for caffeine metabolism and variations on these genes can affect the speed at which we metabolize

title: Caffeine & Sleep
summary:
Unfortunately about 50% of the population roughly are slow caffeine metabolizers, meaning it takes us far longer to get caffeine out of our body.


Many people with PCOS fall into the slow metabolizer category.


If fatigue and sleep issues continue even after implementing your other lifestyle changes, we recommend removing caffeine for at least 2 months, alongside the other lifestyle changes, to see if this improves your energy levels.

title: Why we exercise
body:
In this lesson, we look at what’s really important when it comes to exercise, and how we can build exercise into our lifestyles for the long term.

The most effective exercise is always going to be the one that you do consistently. Think of this as the towards moves you are making to live the life you want to live, controlling your PCOS and root cause.

The best way to do something consistently is finding exercise that you LOVE and you enjoy.

If exercise isn't part of your daily life already, then don't feel like you need to jump in the deep end! Find a form of movement that you feel comfortable doing, and you enjoy. You don't need to hit the gym, or feel exhaustion from exercise so never feel like a workout isn't worthy if it's not one of these two things! Every walk, at home routine, yoga/stretching  session or whatever it is that you choose, is progress and steps in the right direction.

Exercise is for everyone and anyone, regardless of whether weight loss is a goal for you or not.
summary: Our exercise guidelines are just a suggestion, and you might find that you much prefer a different form of exercise. That's absolutely fine, remember, you understand your body best.

title: What does this look like?
body:
We’ve found the most effective exercise for your root cause is a mix of: 
  • Resistance training
  • Low intensity cardio
  • If you like (not essential!), a little bit of high intensity interval training (HIIT) 
An example week could look like:
  • 2-3 x resistance sessions (30-60 minutes)
  • A total of 150 minutes per week of cardio
Remember, any exercise is better than nothing, so if you're time poor, or really struggling with motivation, then doing things like parking your car a 10 minute walk from work so that you get 20 minutes of walking a day is still excellent and a great towards move to add to your week!

title: Give it a go!
body:
If you see no change in 6 months, you're more than welcome to go back to doing what you were doing previously.

But if you're not getting the results that you want now, then what's the risk in changing it and doing something new?

In the next tool kits we’ll talk you through these different types of exercise and how to do them!

title: Exercise Guidelines
body:
Our exercise guidelines are just a suggestion, and you might find that you much prefer a different form of exercise. That's absolutely great, and remember, you understand your body best.

If you're keen to learn more about some forms of exercise that have been shown to be beneficial for your insulin, have a read of this lesson.

title: REST DAYS
body:
Don’t discount rest days!

Rest days are just as important for our health and fitness! This is the time where our body can make adaptations so that the next week we’re stronger and fitter.

Exercising five days a week is plenty, so aim to include 2 rest days.
You can still be active on a rest day, like going for a cycle around your neighbourhood, or a leisurely walk or hike somewhere.

Use these days to get out and have fun!

In fact, rest days are a towards move as they allow the body time to recover. This is essential for long term health and in the short term for stronger and fitter sessions to follow.

title: RESISTANCE TRAINING
body:
*This might sound a little intimidating, so if you're not ready for this yet - that's totally fine! give this one a miss for now, you can always come back to it when you're ready!

We suggest incorporating resistance training as this builds muscle and helps improve your insulin sensitivity.

Resistance training is anything that builds muscle strength by making your muscles work against a force.
If you’re not currently doing any resistance training, you can start with body weight workouts, or strength based yoga or pilates.
But if you really want to see improvements, you won't be able to just do the same workouts over and over again, you'll need to push your body a bit more - this is called progressive overload and is a fundamental rule for improving insulin sensitivity.

How to do this:               
  • Increase reps
  • Increase weight (even if it is just 2.5 lbs)
  • Slow your reps down (to say, 5 seconds)
  • Incorporate 1/4 reps (or pulses)
  • Decrease rest periods
So if you don't have access to weights, you can see that it doesn’t matter. You can do things like slow your reps down, or increase the number of reps.

title: RESISTANCE TRAINING
body:
How intense it should be:

You will feel that this is quite hard, ideally, you should be almost reaching failure at the end of the set of reps.

Try and get to the point where you could only do 2 more reps before you had to stop.

But then you rest and recover for 90 seconds before the next set.      
    
How long it should be:

As long, or as short as you can. While 3 x 45-60 minute sessions per week is brilliant for strengthening muscles, if you can only do 20 minutes, then do that.

Even if you can only do 5 minutes at a time (i.e. 100 squats while you're waiting for your partner to get out of the shower), it all counts!


We've provided lots of example workouts for you, along with tutorials on how to do the exercises.

title: CARDIO
body:
How intense it should be:

Something that gets your heart rate up slightly and sustains it - but not too much.

This will mean some effort and you may sweat a little however you’ll still be able to carry a full conversation and you could keep the same pace up for hours.

In terms of heart rate, this is no higher than 180bpm subtracted by your age (e.g. if you’re 30 this is 180-30= 150bpm, so aim to sit within the 140-150bpm window).

This is the heart rate zone that is best for increasing fitness.

*Note that the 150bpm number is not the average heart rate (i.e you’re not going from 120-180). It is the number you need to stay at or under for the entirety of every cardio workout.  

How long it should be:

Whatever you can make work!

45 minutes each session is optimal for building fitness and stamina, but if you can only do 20 minutes, then do it!

Just aim for a total of 150 minutes each week.

Every minute you can do it a towards move in the right direction!

title: HIIT (High Intensity Interval Training)
body:
NOTE: DOING HIIT IS NOT ESSENTIAL!! But here is some information about how you can incorporate a small amount into your routine if you're really wanting some of those sweaty HIIT endorphins.


HIIT involves short bursts of intense exercise alternated with low-intensity recovery periods. It's become really popular as it's the most time-efficient way to get some sweaty endorphins!

A HIIT workout will range from 10 to 30 minutes in duration, but can be as little as 4 minutes of maximum effort.

As we suspect your adrenals play a role in the root cause of your PCOS, your tolerance for high intensity workouts is much lower than most other people, and this could delay any improvements in your PCOS symptoms. It’s better to do no more than about 4 minutes of the HIIT (max effort) working out at one time. This way, you’re getting the benefits of high intensity (and get a few sweaty endorphins) but won’t suffer the negative effects of cortisol. But remember to check in with yourself, and don’t overdo it!


Remember, check yourself! If you're feeling tired after a workout for more than 15 minutes, you need to back it off.

title: Remember - check yourself!
body:
If you're feeling tired after a workout for more than 15 minutes, you need to back it off.

We've provided lots of example workouts for you, along with tutorials on how to do the exercises.

Remember: You can always chat to your health coach to decide what exercise routine might be good for you.

title: The 5 minute rule
summary:
This is the PERFECT example of a towards move. You don’t need to exercise daily to support your health and PCOS, in fact that could do more harm than good.

BUT, if you have 5 minutes free, maybe even more on some days, take the steps and progress towards the life you want to live.

Choice to make it happen, it’s only 5 minutes!

title: Weight Loss & Exercise
body:
When it comes to weight loss, exercise is not essential but it does make it much easier, and we think it makes you feel better and more motivated!

Focus on doing something that you LOVE. It might not fit the guidelines here, and that's okay.

It's much more important that you do something consistently.

If you don't love it, it's unlikely that you'll be able to sustain it. We really encourage you to exercise for reasons other than weight loss.

title: What about burning calories?
summary:
Audio summary:

  • The weight loss calorie equation (calories in < calories out/ burned = calorie deficit) doesn’t work if our hormones aren’t functioning properly.
  • Our bodies aren’t burning stored fat for energy, or storing food energy properly thanks to our insulin not functioning properly
  • We can use exercise as a tool to get our insulin functioning better (resistance training), and do exercise that can help our body to burn stored body fat (cardio within the heart rate zone)


Extra for experts: There is some evidence that doing your cardio fasted (i.e. before breakfast), may be more beneficial for weight loss, but it's only a minor improvement so don’t stress yourself out trying to achieve this.

title: 1. Schedule it into your calendar!
body:
This seems so straightforward but it is the most important tip!

If you haven’t blocked out some time in your day to do your exercise, the day will fly by before you know it and any opportunity to exercise will likely be gobbled up!

Be sure to think about when your most likely and enjoyable time to exercise will be, and schedule it accordingly. If you’re not a morning person and you’re always scheduling (and missing) morning workouts, then booking in a lunchtime session might be better suited.

title: 2. Preparation
body:
Equipment & Gear:

Think about what gear you might need to workout in e.g. do you have comfortable shoes and clothing to workout in?

If not, it might be worthwhile investing in some quality gear to make exercise more enjoyable and reduce your risk for injury from not so great footwear.

And, have you got access to the equipment you need to do the workout you want e.g. can you access a gym, do you have equipment at home?

If you don’t plan to use any equipment for your workout, for example pilates or body weight exercises then that’s great!


Eating around exercise:

Depending on the workout you do, you might want to consider what food you eat before and after to make the best use of your workout, and help avoid any digestion issues during your workout.

title: 3. Use your habit stacking
body:
Stack exercise on another habit to help it stick!

For example, when you first wake up you already have a habit of jumping into the shower. Why not do 10 minutes of body weight exercises on your bedroom floor before you jump in?

Over time, once you’re so used to doing some exercise before you start your day, you might do this 20 or 30 minutes of exercise.

And eventually you might move your workout to your spare room or garage, and add in some weighted exercises using some cheap dumbbells you’ve purchased. . .

You’ve effectively used a habit that already existed, to help guide you into a new habit with exercise!

title: Module Overview
body:
This module will cover some additional information you can use to help with one of the frustrating symptoms of PCOS, weight gain. Your root cause is still the most important thing to improve your ability to lose weight and maintain a lower body weight, but these are the additional things that can support your efforts of weight loss. Over the next 5 lessons we’ll be covering these topics:
  1. An introduction to PCOS weight gain and my root cause
  2. What’s causing my weight loss
  3. When calories are important - energy balance for weight loss
  4. Body neutrality
  5. How to track success
  6. Medical treatments to support weight loss

title: Weight & Your PCOS
summary:
Audio Summary:

  • Weight gain (and finding it really hard to lose weight) is a very common symptom of PCOS
  • Simply reducing your calories and increasing your exercise will not allow you to lose weight, unlike for those who do not have PCOS
  • Instead, our hormones that our out of balance (insulin and testosterone) change the way our body metabolizes and stores energy
  • These hormonal imbalance cause a negative cycle by further increasing weight gain which then causes even more of a hormonal imbalance
  • This is as adipose (fat) tissue produces testosterone, and insulin affects our fat storage and burning mechanisms
  • We need to work on rebalancing our hormones through lifestyle changes and combine this with both a (sensible and sustainable) calorie deficit and exercise plan to most effectively lose weight

title: The journey rather than the destination
body:
We don’t recommend focusing all your attention on a goal weight, and using this as your measure of success, as this mindset can be hampering.

It only sets us up for disappointment if it’s taking too long to reach

Instead, we come back to the small wins mentality

This is as the positive benefits of improving your hormones and lifestyle habits, don’t only arrive when we see the scale move, but instead continue to come along the journey to that destination.

We don’t want to miss these small victories, like more energy, or sleeping soundly through the whole night, if we’re too busy focused on what the scale says.

title: Throw away your scales
body:
On that note, we’d really recommend that you actually throw away your scales (or ask someone to hide these from you).

The scales can be the biggest demotivator in your weight loss journey 

As you now understand that weight-loss in PCOS is all about balancing hormones AND calories, and this can take some time.

So you may not see weight loss immediately. This doesn’t mean that you’re not working towards this but it just needs extra time.

If you’re looking for feedback from the scale that these changes are ‘working’, you might not get that feedback, and may give up too soon.

In an upcoming tool kit we’ll explain a little more on why we don’t love the scales, and how to measure your weight loss in a more motivating way.

title: Body Neutrality
body:
It is really hard to change habits when we come to habit change hating our bodies.

While we don’t have to suddenly love everything about our bodies, it’s really helpful to move towards body neutrality.


What is body neutrality?  

Body neutrality is about taking a neither positive, nor negative view on our body image, rather simply taking a neutral view - no judgement.

Body neutrality instead focuses on what our bodies can do, rather than what they look like

It’s about being grateful for the way our body can move, and carry us through this world - from hiking and swimming to enjoying tastes and loved ones - and about honoring our bodies with the nourishment and compassion to continue to do so.

title: Body Neutrality
body:
We might not love our thighs, but we are grateful for them so we can enjoy a walk along the beach

Imperfections exist, and for all of us these look different.

So body neutrality is about accepting we have them, rather than ignoring them or glorifying them, but simply not associating any feelings with them.

We might not love our stretch marks, but we are grateful to our body for giving birth

title: Body Neutrality
body:
The body positivity movement has been a community conversation that strives for equality for all body types and imperfections, and promotes that you can be happy at any size - to love your body no matter what.

But sometimes this level of positivity doesn’t feel particularly authentic or it can make us feel like a bit of a fraud, because we truly aren’t ‘happy’ with our body.

And you know what, that is okay!

This is where body neutrality can be such a beneficial and empowering space to be in, as it can feel much more authentic.

It can help us to find acceptance in our body weight, shape or flaws whilst still working towards health and fitness goals that we have.

If you want to move more towards a body neutrality mindset, we highly recommend booking a consultation with an expert. Here you can discuss actions and tools to help you achieve a more neutral relationship with your body.

title: Throw out your scales
body:
(or put them somewhere you can't get to them)


We’ve all had the experience when we’ve gone on a diet, have been really ‘good’ all week, then we hop on the scales expecting to be rewarded for all our hard work, only to see the scale hasn’t moved, or it’s even gone up. Subsequently, the diet goes out the window, when it actually probably had nothing to do with the diet.

Firstly, it’s not actually all about the ‘weight’, despite popular belief.

What we want to focus on doing is changing our body composition

This means we focus on losing adipose (fat) tissue (the one that’s annoyingly producing more testosterone) and focus on increasing our muscle mass, which makes our body more sensitive to insulin and naturally burns more calories (as muscle cells require much more energy than fat cells do).

title: Throw out your scales
body:
But, changing our body composition in this way doesn’t necessarily mean weight loss.

We only have to google fat vs. muscle to see that fat takes up much more space than muscle, and muscle is much denser and therefore, heavier.  

This means we can weigh the same but then have a completely different body shape.

Consequently, the scale is the ultimate mind messer!

On top of this, our body weight will fluctuate daily (in as much as 2kg swings!).

What can cause our scale weight to fluctuate?
  • Where we are in our menstrual cycle
  • If we’ve done strenuous exercise or not
  • How well we’ve slept
  • If we’ve gone to the loo today or not
  • Medications
  • Water intake (or lack thereof)
  • Alcohol intake
  • If we’ve gained or lost muscle
  • Slow progression in weight loss

So, please don’t use scales as your method to track your progress.

title: Measurements
body:
Instead, we'd love you to use measurements to track your progress.

Those of us with insulin resistant PCOS generally deposit a lot of our fat gained around our midsection.
