So when we start improving our insulin resistance, that's where we'll start to see changes first.

Our clothes will start to feel looser and eventually we’ll visually see the weight coming off there.

How to do this:

Measure your waist circumference (just above your belly button, the smallest part of your waist) and your hip circumference (the widest part of your bottom) at roughly the same time of day.

Record this in your Apple health app.

title: Photos
body:
In addition to measurements, you can also take photos (every month or 6 weeks only) so over time you can see your progress side by side visually.

How to do this:

Take photos from the front, side and back ideally wearing the same underwear, in the same mirror, at roughly the same time of day.

Only do these recordings every 4-6 weeks.

It’s important not to get too granular or frequent with tracking as with these methods we can still see slight fluctuations and it can be a demotivator or cause disappointment waiting for each inch lost.

title: Weekly Wins
body:
We love a weekly win!

Reflect back on what you’ve done well this week. Maybe that’s making a change to your breakfast,or getting a better sleep, or you didn’t crave sugar as much as you usually do.

Rather than looking for visual signs of weight loss, look to the positive habits you’re changing and the great results you’re gaining from that.

Your worth isn’t determined by a number on the scale or a measurement, and we really want to stop any bad habits of berating or judging yourself because of it.

title: Medical Treatments
body:
Medical, particularly surgical, intervention isn’t for everyone, and we’re not suggesting it is essential by any means.

However, we want you to know that these options are available so you can make the best choice for yourself.

We know how hard weight loss can be with PCOS, as so we want you to know all the options available to you, both lifestyle and medical.

title: Surgical Treatments
body:
Bariatric Surgery      
                
Bariatric surgery has shown to be a successful option for significant weight loss in people with PCOS (generally only considered if you have a BMI > 35).

Bariatric surgery can be successful long term, because it improves the root cause of insulin resistance and high androgens (testosterone). In fact, it can reverse over 90% of type 2 diabetes cases in people with PCOS, and improvements in insulin resistance happen immediately after surgery, even before any weight loss.

In terms of symptoms, bariatric surgery regulates menstrual cycles (and therefore improves fertility) in 77% of people, improves or even eliminates hirsutism in over 50% of cases, improves testosterone levels (which drive acne and hair loss) by over 60%,

title: Surgical Treatments
body:
Bariatric Surgery      

There are choices when it comes to the procedures you can receive, with the most commonly performed surgery being the Vertical Sleeve Gastrectomy (VSG), and secondly the Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass (RYGB).

These are different methods by which the stomach is resected or partially diverted in a way that alters the shape and size of the stomach, as well as the hormones associated with hunger.

As with all surgical procedures, these operations do pose very real risk and can be unsuccessful with assisting weight loss.

We strongly recommend you speak to your PCP or FMD about all the options, risks and requirements for bariatric surgery if this is something you are considering.

title: Medical Treatments
body:
Orlistat (Trade names Xenical and Alli)

Orlistat is a drug called a lipase inhibitor that works to block the absorption of dietary fats, and must be taken in conjunction with a low fat (less than 30% of your energy intake) and low calorie diet that’s high in vegetables and fruit.

The unabsorbed fat is passed in your stools. Consuming more fat will mean side effects of the drug are worsened (loser, more frequent, urgent or uncontrollable fatty stools are most common).  

A 2018 review of the effectiveness of orlistat in people with PCOS has shown it to be successful in reducing weight loss as well as improving insulin resistance.

It has also shown to help rebalance hormones associated with reproduction leading to positive fertility and pregnancy outcomes.  

Note: As less fat is absorbed, this drug can significantly affect your absorption of fat-soluble vitamins such as vitamin A, K, E and D. It’s important you are supplementing and monitoring your nutrient levels whilst taking this drug.

title: Medical Treatments
body:
GLP-1 Agonists (multiple trade names exist such as Ozempic and Saxenda)

GLP-1 agonists are glucose-lowering medications, and are essentially the new drug on the block for type 2 diabetes and weight loss, and have shown significant results in these areas (much more so than Metformin, an insulin sensitising drug).

While this drug is relatively new, it’s showing that it may be as effective as bariatric surgery.  In the initial trials, more than 50% of people have lost more than 15% of their body weight, and improved insulin by over 25%.

The way they achieve this effect in weight loss, is by improving insulin and also suppressing appetite.

title: Medical Treatments
body:
GLP-1 Agonists (multiple trade names exist such as Ozempic and Saxenda)

The main side effect of GLP-1 agonists is nausea, which affects about 40% of people. It can help to increase the dose really slowly to reduce this.

PCOS-specific Research
A recent meta-analysis (a gold standard study that looks at all of the most current studies to draw a conclusion) showed that GLP-1 agonists were superior to metformin at increasing insulin sensitivity, reducing BMI and reducing waist circumference, whilst reducing the number of side effects relating to nausea and headaches.

As they are so new they may not be available in all countries, or may be cost prohibitive.

title: Hair Removal Techniques
body:
The following treatments alone won’t improve your hirsutism.

You can use them, but in terms of getting permanent hair reduction, you also need to work on bringing down your androgen levels.

A multi-pronged approach tends to be the most effective when it comes to reducing hirsutism.

title: Shaving, waxing, plucking and threading
body:
These are all different ways to mechanically remove the hair from the follicle.

Mechanically removing the hair doesn't kill the hair over the long-term (despite the old wives tale (of which there’s no evidence for) that if you pluck a hair enough it’ll eventually stop growing back).

The hair tends to grow back relatively quickly so it may be an inconvenient option if you have quite severe hirsutism.

Risk: Low
Cost: $
Long term efficacy: Poor

title: IPL and Laser
body:
IPL and laser use light to kill the hair follicle at the root to stop it from growing again.

IPL uses pulsed light while laser uses a concentrated beam of light.

Because they're using light, they can do a relatively large section at a time. It also doesn’t tend to be too painful.

You will need to have multiple appointments for a longer term hair reduction effect.

For women with PCOS, research is showing that IPL and laser hair removal tend to be the best options to use alongside working on your root cause.

Risk: Moderate
Cost: $$
Long term efficacy: High

title: Electrolysis
body:
Electrolysis is a method of removing individual hairs from the face or body.

It destroys the hair follicle with chemical or heat energy, then the hair is removed with tweezers, making for a lengthy process.

Risk: Low
Cost: $$$
Long term efficacy: High

title: Medical Treatments
body:
These types of medication aren't for everyone, and we’re not suggesting medication is essential by any means, however we want you to know that these options are available so you can make the best choice for yourself.

The medications we’ll be looking at are:
  • The Oral Contraceptive Pill
  • Spironolactone
  • Flutamide
  • Finasteride

Important Note
  • It’s important to remember not every person taking medications will experience all of the pros and cons associated with its use.
  • As we can’t diagnose or prescribe, we suggest you speak with your doctor and/or dermatologist about what’s right for you. They will be able to help you decide on the right choice based on your medical history and symptoms as well as prescribe what you decide on.
  • Make sure to check that there are no contraindications between any medication listed with any other supplements or medications you’re currently taking - as well as with any conditions you may have.

title: The Oral Contraceptive Pill (OCP)
body:
The hormonal birth control (HBC) pill is the most common drug for hirsutism.


How does it work?

It works to reduce androgens therefore helps to reduce PCOS symptoms including hirsutism.


Form

There are a number of different HBC options with varying concentrations of synthetic progestogen and estrogen which have shown to have different levels of anti-androgenic effects.

The combined hormonal birth control pill (combined meaning both synthetic progestogen and estrogen) specifically has been shown to be most effective (e.g. Diane-35 or Yasmin).

title: Spironolactone (Aldactone)
body:
Spironolactone (Aldactone) is an oral medication which has anti-androgenic effects therefore is commonly prescribed to people with PCOS to help manage hirsutism.

How does it work?

Spironolactone is basically a synthetic steroid drug, which affects our body’s normal hormone function.

If you think of the lock and key analogy where locks are cells and hormones are keys, pseudo-hormones like spironolactone are the same fit as a certain hormone, so it fits into the lock the hormone usually would, but instead, they signal for a different action.

Spironolactone mimics testosterone, so if it’s already in the lock, testosterone can’t come and work its DHT-hirsutism causing magic.

Dosage

The therapeutic dose for hirsutism therapy is about 100-300mg per day but this will depend on your situation and your hirsutism. However, they might recommend you start with 25mg a day and slowly up your dose over time to help reduce your risk of the potential side effects.

Spironolactone is generally used in combination with the OCP, both for contraception (as you can’t get pregnant on it as it can cause birth defects) and to make the anti-androgenic effects more potent.

Side effects

Spironolactone can have potential side effects including feeling really thirsty, needing to pee more often, fatigue and headaches.

title: Flutamide
body:
Flutamide is commonly used to treat PCOS hirsutism and hair loss (as well as acne to a lesser extent, and prostate cancer in males).

How does it work?

Flutamide is a drug that blocks testosterone from being converted into DHT (testosterone’s more potent form) in the same mechanism as spironolactone.

Side effects

There is a very real risk that flutamide can cause liver failure, especially in young females, so it’s not without risk.

If you have been prescribed it, make sure your doctor is checking your liver bloods regularly. And if you have fatty liver caused by insulin resistance or diabetes, it might not be the best choice.

Dosage

Anywhere between 62.5-500mg per day can be prescribed, depending on the situation but the jury is still out on what the most effective dosage is.

Just like spironolactone, flutamide is generally used in combination with the OCP, both for contraception (as flutamide can also cause birth defects) and for anti-androgenic potency.

Because of the significant risk for liver damage, flutamide isn’t often used as a first-line; and if it is, the lowest effective dose is usually recommended along with close monitoring.

title: Finasteride
body:
How does it work?

Just like spironolactone and flutamide, finasteride is another drug that also blocks DHT and is commonly used in treating hirsutism.

Dosage

Therapeutic dosages range between about 2-5mg per day. Again you also can’t get pregnant when on finasteride as it has the potential to cause birth defects.

Side effects

Like any drug, finasteride comes with side effects, the most common being loss of libido and dry skin.

title: Bariatric Surgery
body:
Bariatric surgery (such as a gastric band or gastric sleeve) has been found to be really effective in improving hirsutism for those that also have weight gain with their PCOS. Bariatric surgery lowers your insulin and blood sugar, which in turn lowers testosterone. 

An analysis of all the studies on bariatric surgery and PCOS found that on average, it reduces hirsutism by over 50%. As you know, it’s not the only thing that can improve insulin and testosterone, but if you’re really struggling with weight gain as well, it’s important to know that bariatric surgery is another option.

title: Still unsure?
body:
Unsure whether any of these medical interventions will suit you, or undecided whether to give them a go?

Feel free to speak to your expert about what might be the best option for you.

title: Hello and Welcome!
body:
Firstly, we want to say well done and we’re so proud of you - you’ve made a big step towards reversing all of those awful PCOS symptoms you’ve been dealing with.

Prioritizing YOUR health isn’t easy, but it’s damn important!

We know you're probably feeling like you’ve tried everything and nothing has worked. We’ve been where you are, and we know just how debilitating both the physical and emotional symptoms of PCOS can be.

But it doesn’t have to be that way.

We also want you to know that your symptoms really can improve and you don’t have to give up every food and everything you enjoy in your life to see improvements. Now that we understand your symptoms and ‘root cause’, we can give you small, specific changes that are going to make a big difference.

We'll deliver learning modules that are specific to YOU. Each module will walk you through a lifestyle change that’s specifically designed to target the root cause of your PCOS and works to reverse your symptoms.

title: What to expect
body:
How will this program work?

  • We use your answers to the questionnaire to tailor the information you receive right down to the exact lessons, eating and supplement recommendations to support your personal PCOS symptoms and root cause.


  • We’ll deliver over the coming weeks information in the form of lessons, tool kits and recipes, as well as challenge you with tasks and quizzes to help you to implement the changes.


  • These lessons and activities will belong to a module, and each module will be a habit change you’ll be making.


  • Lessons and other activities will ‘unlock’ one-by-one daily, as we drip feed the information. This is because to make sustainable habit changes that will last you for a lifetime, working through them one-by-one is the best practice for success. This will give you a chance to digest the information, and implement the change.

title: Clare's PCOS Journey
summary:
Clare Goodwin - Founder of Ovie
Registered Nutritionist & Exercise Scientist
PCOS advocate

title: My Root Cause
body:
PCOS is a constellation of a broad range of symptoms.

No two women experience PCOS the same, so there’s not a ‘one size fits all’ treatment.

That’s why we’ve created a program specific to your root cause of PCOS, which we can deduce from your specific symptoms.
summary:
What’s my root cause?

This is what we suspect is the main driver of your PCOS symptoms. If we focus on tackling the root cause of your PCOS, overtime we can help reverse the symptoms.

From our questionnaire we've identified that your insulin is one of the main drivers of your PCOS.

title: What is insulin?
body:
Insulin is a hormone in our body that’s released by our pancreas when we eat - especially when we eat carbohydrates.

Our bodies break down the carbohydrates we’ve eaten into a simple sugar (glucose) which is then absorbed into our bloodstream. Glucose is delivered to all of our cells to be utilized for energy. We have mitochondria which are like little motors inside our cells that work to convert the glucose into energy - pretty cool.

But . . for that glucose molecule to get to the mitochondria it needs to get inside the cell.

Imagine your cell has a locked door and this hormone, insulin, is the key to that lock.

We need insulin to come to and unlock the door to let the glucose inside.

title: What is insulin?
body:
With insulin resistance, it's like the lock has become a little bit jammed up and insulin wiggling the key around with no luck. So it has to recruit more insulin molecules to come and help, hoping that one will have a key that fits, or they can bash the door down.  

In the early stages of insulin resistance, you might only need an extra 20 molecules, but if insulin resistance progresses too long, you might need an extra  50, 100 or even 200 molecules of insulin to do this same job.  

Eventually the organ that produces your insulin, your pancreas will become overworked and won’t be able to produce enough insulin to keep up with the demand (this is type 2 diabetes).

As insulin resistance develops progressively, the earlier we catch it and implement changes to reverse it, the better.

title: Your PCOS Symptom of Weight
body:
Insulin is a fat storage hormone, so when our body is producing a lot of insulin, it makes it really easy to gain weight (even when we’re not eating much), and much harder to lose weight. How do we know this?

Really interesting research has shown that if you inject people with more and more insulin, they’ll gain weight, even if they are eating less! 

High levels of insulin also stimulate testosterone to be produced, and this can further drive weight gain. Not only this, the additional weight then makes our insulin resistance worse, leading to further testosterone production and further weight gain ... It's a vicious cycle!

title: My PCOS Symptom of Weight
body: This is why you can feel like you follow all the rules about eating less and exercising more and not lose much weight at all, or even gain weight! Eating less and exercising more simply isn’t going to break the vicious cycle - it’s probably just going to break you!
summary: Instead, we need to reduce how much insulin our body is producing. We can do this through modifying what and when we eat, how we move and sleep, as well as providing our bodies with the right vitamins and minerals to assist with this. That’s what you’ll be learning and implementing over the next few weeks!

title: My PCOS Symptom of Hirsutism
body:
We all have little fine vellus hairs that cover our body, or peach fuzz as you might know it as, that can barely be seen. But in PCOS, we have too many androgen hormones (like testosterone, DHEAS and androstenedione) which then convert into the more potent dihydrotestosterone (DHT).

This DHT gets into the follicles in places like the face, back and chest and causes these vellus hairs to be converted to thick terminal hairs that are much more visible.

High levels of insulin affects our sex hormone production, increasing androgen hormones to be produced (hirsutism-stimulating), and reducing production of sex hormone binding globulin (SHBG).

SHBG is like a sponge that goes around your body and mops up excess androgens. So if you have less sponges, there are more androgens to get into your hair follicles and cause hirsutism.

So if we can reduce insulin, we reduce androgens, and we can reduce the appearance of hirsutism.

  • Firstly, we strongly recommend listening to this audio rather than only skimming the summary notes for this lesson!
  • Cultivating a deeper, stronger “why compass” is key to continuing to make moves towards adopting new lifestyle changes
  • Having that strong ‘why’, one that comes from a place of self-compassion and is a mantra like “I deserve better” really helps when you feel yourself spiraling. 
  • For example, saying “you know what? I deserve better. I deserve to treat myself to going to the gym, to looking after myself so that I can then look after the other people that I love in my life and do the things that I love, like hiking, with them.”

title: Module Overview
body:
In this module we’re specifically addressing arguably the peskiest of PCOS symptoms, hirsutism.

We’ll unpack exactly how our root cause drives hirsutism, as well as ways we can help to manage our symptom of hirsutism, whilst we work on our root cause to reduce the growth of the dark terminal hairs.

Over the next 3 lessons we’ll be looking at:
  1. What’s causing my PCOS hirsutism?
  2. Hair removal techniques
  3. Medical options to help manage hirsutism
Today, we’ll be starting with an overview of how your PCOS root cause can lead to hirsutism.

title: Hirsutism & My Root Cause
body:
Hirsutism is one of the more common symptoms of PCOS, with upwards of 75% of people diagnosed with PCOS presenting with hirsutism.

Hirsutism can be defined as terminal hairs which are usually dark and longer than 5mm. Hirsutism in PCOS is typically seen on the upper lip, chin and neck, chest and abdomen, thighs, back and upper arms.

We all have little fine vellus hairs that cover our body, or peach fuzz as you might know it as, that can barely be seen. But in PCOS, we have too many androgen hormones (like testosterone, DHEAS and androstenedione) which then convert into the more potent dihydrotestosterone (DHT).

This DHT gets into the follicles in places like the face, back and chest and causes these vellus hairs to be converted to thick terminal hairs that are much more visible.

title: Hirsutism & My Root Cause
body:
High levels of insulin affects our sex hormone production, increasing testosterone to be produced (hirsutism-stimulating), and reducing production of sex hormone binding globulin (SHBG). SHBG is like a sponge that goes around your body and mops up excess testosterone.

So if you have less sponges, there is more testosterone to get into your hair follicles and cause hirsutism. High stress also exacerbates this as it causes more sugar to be released into our blood (this is the fight or flight response in action). This means our body has to release even more insulin to transport all that blood sugar, as well, it can also lead to even more androgen production.

A double whammy! So if we can reduce insulin AND stress, we can reduce testosterone, the appearance of hirsutism.

title: Weight Gain & My Root Cause
body:
Insulin is a fat storage hormone, so when our body is producing a lot of insulin, it makes it really easy to gain weight (even when we’re not eating much), and much harder to lose weight.

How do we know this?

Really interesting research has shown that if you inject people with more and more insulin, they’ll gain weight, even if they are eating less!

High stress also exacerbates this. High levels of stress causes sugar to be released into our bloodstream (a survival mechanism to give us energy to ‘fight’ or ‘flee’). This means our body has to release even more insulin to transport all that blood sugar.

High levels of insulin also stimulate testosterone to be produced, and this can further drive weight gain. Not only this, the additional weight then makes our insulin resistance worse, leading to further testosterone production and further weight gain ... It's a vicious cycle! 

This is why you can feel like you follow all the rules about eating less and exercising more and not lose much weight at all, or even gain weight!

title: Weight Gain & My Root Cause
body:
In order to achieve your weight loss goal, we need to address two equally important parts:
  1. Your insulin and stress hormones AND
  2. Your energy balance. 
Eating less and exercising more simply isn’t going to break the vicious cycle - it’s probably just going to break you!

Instead, we need to reduce how much insulin our body is producing. We can do this through modifying what and when we eat, how we move and sleep, as well as providing our bodies with the right vitamins and minerals to assist with this.

That’s what you’ll be learning and implementing over the next few weeks! The energy balance part we’ll cover in the next lesson.

title: Energy Balance
body:
In order to lose weight (body fat), we need to force our body to burn fat. This isn’t something that our body really wants to do, it would rather protect our fat stores for survival. So we really have to give it a good reason to do this.  

This is by eating less energy than we’re burning, so that it has to actually make up the deficit by burning our body fat for said energy.

If your body is burning 2000 calories a day, and you only feed it 1500 calories, it needs to make up that 500 calories from somewhere. This is where in an ideal world, it would burn some of your body fat to make up this extra 500 calories, and you would lose weight (body fat).

However, for most people with PCOS that have been trying to lose weight, there are a few things that stop this from happening.  

1. Hormones: If your insulin or stress hormones are too high, this will make losing weight very difficult (that’s why we’re spending so much time focusing on your hormones within the program).

2. Energy: You’ve been eating too little for too long. This is much more common than you might think! We see that this is the case in about 85% of Ovie’s!

title: Energy Deficit
body:
In order to lose weight, we need to be eating about 20% less than what we’re burning.

Because our bodies want us to hold onto our weight for survival (we can’t just keep losing weight until we die), they have many clever ways to prevent weight loss from happening.

One of these ways is to adjust our metabolism, so that they become really efficient with a smaller amount of energy.

When we’re dieting for a long period of time, this is what our body will do to stop us losing weight - our body slows our metabolism.

This is why we can be eating very little, even 1200 calories and still not be losing weight.

title: How do we achieve a deficit?
body:
So how do we get around this if we’re already eating so little? Don’t worry, it’s not to eat even less! 

It might actually mean that you need to eat a little bit more for a period of time, to kick start your metabolism, before cutting back.

The exact amount is different for all of us, because it depends on our lifestyle, how responsive our metabolism is and also how much we’re currently eating. It’s not an easy science - this is what our experts have spent years learning.

We’d recommend that you book a consultation with your expert here so that they can assess your needs and provide a tailored approach for you.

Alternatively, you can calculate what you’re currently eating and then reduce this by about 20%.

However, we’d caution you to not go below 1400 calories, as this is where it can actually have the opposite effect!

title: Do you actually need supplements?
body:
Do you actually need supplements? You may have heard before that “you shouldn't need any vitamins and mineral supplements if you have a balanced diet”. What they're basing that statement off is that:
You’re just not deficient in that vitamin, AND
That you’re an average person without any other health conditions going on (no PCOS, no inflammation or no insulin resistance for example)


In PCOS, targeted supplementation and a balanced diet that are both designed with your root cause in mind is the most effective approach. It’s still best that you get as much nutrients as possible from your food, but that doesn’t mean that you’ll necessarily be getting everything you need without supplements.

title: What supplements might help your PCOS symptoms
body:
What supplements might help your PCOS symptoms is very dependent on a number of factors, including:

Your root cause
Whether you only have suboptimal levels of vitamins and minerals, whether you have a full-blown deficiency
Whether you’re trying to conceive
Your genetics (this can play a role in your ability to convert the nutrients we get from food into the biologically active form e.g. beta-carotene into vitamin A)

Before you start taking anything, please check in with your doctor, especially if you're taking medication or you're pregnant. They know your health best.

In the next tool kit we’ll take you through our recommendations for supplements to help improve your insulin.

title: Insulin
body:
Insulin requires a lot of vitamins and minerals to function properly as these are cofactors in the reaction of the insulin ‘key’ fitting into the receptor ‘lock’. If your insulin isn’t working optimally, our aim is to improve your cell’s ‘lock’ sensitivity to the key so it opens more quickly. The quicker that key turns the less insulin our body produces.

These supplements recommended are nutrients that are essential for your insulin to work properly (those cofactors), as well as the supplements that have most research evidence for improving insulin sensitivity.

title: Your supplement plan
body:
This is by no means an exhaustive list, however, we’ve tried to narrow down the most important supplements for you, based on the latest research on your specific type of PCOS. We don’t want you having to take hundreds of different supplements and so we’ve worked really hard to narrow these down to just the most important for you.

These are listed in order of importance, so if you only want to take 1-2, start with those at the top of this list.

Before we get started:

These are just our suggestions, as always, please check with your doctor first before taking any new supplements, especially if you are on any medication

Please see the links below for where to order in different countries

Those marked with an asterix (*) contain herbs and are not recommended during pregnancy or breastfeeding

We strongly recommend finishing this module before ordering any supplements

title: Your supplement plan
body: This tool kit highlights the most important supplements to support what we suspect is the root cause of your PCOS symptoms.

title: Blood Biomarkers
body:
There are a number of nutrients that having a low amount in your body (this can be either sub-optimal or a deficiency) can affect your PCOS root cause as well as your overall health, mood or energy level.

With some nutrients toxic levels can build up in our bodies which can have just as detrimental an effect as a deficiency.
 
We want to get you into the functional (optimal) range for the below nutrients.
Note: the functional range can be quite different to the lab or reference range.

For this reason we always recommend testing the following nutrients before beginning any supplementation of these.

You can order your own blood tests from the following sites, alternatively you can request these from your FMD or PCP.


From here, you can book a consultation with your expert to discuss a personalized action plan for you.

title: Vitamin D
body:
Vitamin D, or the sunshine vitamin, is an essential vitamin for many of our body systems, including for our insulin to work properly. Vitamin D has been shown to be low in 67-85% of people with PCOS, particularly in those with insulin resistance, and emerging research is suggesting supplementation has a positive influence on anti-mullerian hormone levels and menstruation.

If your tests show you are low in vitamin D we suggest booking a consultation with your expert to discuss a supplement plan to get you back into the functional range.

title: Iron
body:
Iron is crucial in transporting oxygen around our body to all of our cells, and typically reproductive aged females are most prone to iron deficiencies however this can differ for those of us with PCOS.

Instead, iron overload (too much iron) is common in PCOS, and not because of irregular periods, but due to our insulin not functioning properly.

When testing, be sure to ask for a full iron panel that includes ferritin.

If your tests show you are either deficient in or have high levels of iron we suggest booking a consultation with your expert to discuss a supplement plan to get you back into the functional range.

title: Zinc
body:
Zinc is an essential mineral that’s involved in a whole range of processes including fertility, oestrogen levels, mood, insulin activity and glucose metabolism. Low levels of zinc is common in people with PCOS, and supplementation has shown to be beneficial for helping PCOS symptoms like acne, hair loss and hirsutism. This is because zinc inhibits testosterone from converting into the pesky DHT that causes these symptoms. 

If your tests show you are deficient in or have high levels of zinc we suggest booking a consultation with your expert to discuss a supplement plan to get you back into the functional range.

title: Lifestyle factors
body:
Depending on your diet or lifestyle, there are some additional supplements that can greatly support your PCOS root cause and symptoms:
Omega-3 fish oils
Prebiotics
Probiotics

You can supplement with these without requiring testing, however they can be expensive so if you’re unsure whether these will be beneficial for you, we recommend booking a consultation with your expert.

title: Habit Stacking
body:
A habit expert, James Clear teaches us that habit stacking is one of the best ways to teach your brain a new habit.

Our brains have a number of different synapses that connect all the neurons in our brains. Over our lifetime any connections that are used frequently become stronger - this is where the sentiment “train your brain” comes from. The synapses that are involved with our daily habits and routines are some of these strong synapses, for example brushing your teeth or having a cup of tea in the morning.

It takes time to form new synapses, particularly as we get older and our adult brain is already wired strongly to the way we have been living our lives. So rather than fighting the current, it’s better to go with it, and use the habits that we already have to help us build new ones.

For a new habit you want to implement, for example, remembering to take your supplements daily, try doing this right after or just before a current habit you already have, such as when you eat your breakfast. As you already have a breakfast routine established, using this as a reminder to take your supplements right after will help you to remember to implement your new habit. Overtime, remember to take your supplements will become a thoughtless habit.

title: Habit Stacking
body: Top Tip: Make sure to make your habit stacking plan very clear. If you’re too vague it can be too hard to implement or too easy to forget e.g. I will have my supplements at breakfast verus I will have my supplements once I’ve rinsed and stacked my breakfast plates in the dishwasher.

title: How to begin supplementing
body:
Some people have reactions to some supplements. These can be anything from an upset tummy, gas, bloating, nausea, or even a rash and many other symptoms (if this happens please STOP taking the supplements).

If this were to happen, starting with all the supplements at once would mean you wouldn’t be able to pinpoint which supplement it was that gave you the reaction. To ensure you know that a supplement is sitting okay in your body, we highly recommend starting each new supplement one-by-one, with at least 7-10 between each new supplement.

This also allows our body to get used to the new herbs, vitamins and minerals, rather than bombarding it with a bunch of new things all at once!

Gluten and Inflammation
body:
Audio summary:
  • When inflammation or thyroid issues are at play, it can be worth considering how much gluten is in your diet.
  • Gluten is a molecule humans don’t have the enzyme to breakdown, so depending
  • Coeliac disease is a serious autoimmune response to gluten, however non-coeliac gluten sensitivity is chronic inflammation in the intestine as a result of gluten exposure, typically intensified when additional inflammatory issues are at play. Both can be uncomfortable or do long term damage to our intestines when gluten is continually exposed.
  • If you don’t have coeliac disease, we suggest removing gluten for a short time frame, around 3 months, to see if this has any impact on your symptoms or how you feel, before reintroducing this again.
  • ** This does not mean you need to avoid gluten for the rest of your life, however your tolerance for gluten might be lessened due to other inflammatory elements or thyroid concerns currently at play.

title: Foods that can have hidden sources of gluten
Podcast
body: Click here to listen to more in a podcast on: Should I go gluten free to help my PCOS symptoms?

title: By the way... this is NOT a diet
summary:
Audio summary
  • This is not a diet!! This program is all about learning long-term, sustainable lifestyle changes that work for YOU - your body, your symptoms and your life.
  • We’ll drip-feed you your tailored information daily, so that you have time to digest the information and put it into practice before beginning the next change.

title: Towards and Away Moves
summary:
Audio Summary:
  • We can become hooked and stuck with thoughts that may help in the short term, but take us away from the live we want to live.
  • We see these thoughts as absolute truths, as opposed to seeing thoughts for what they are: thoughts.
  • Rule, reasons, judgments, past, future and self are ways our mind ‘hooks’ to thoughts. Next time you might be stuck on a thought, think about if one of these applies?
  • We have a choice and hold the power. We can choose to let these thoughts hook us, and drag us into an away move, OR we can choose to see these thoughts for what they are and make a towards move.
  • We can use unhooking strategies to separate our thoughts and remove the power they may hold.

title: The 80/20 Philosophy & Perfectionism
summary:
Audio Summary: 
We really want you to discard the ‘all or nothing’ and the diet mindsets, because they’re far more damaging to both your mental and physical health than having the occasional cookie.
Instead, we strongly recommend following these 2 philosophies:
  1. Perfection is unattainable and unsustainable. Just like starting a new sport or job, you’re not going to be perfect from the get-go. Focus instead on making the effort and continuing to improve.

  2. Go for an 80/20 approach when it comes to lifestyle changes. This means focus on eating healthy or following a good sleep and exercise routine 80% of the time. The other 20% is up to you. This 20% buffer allows you to have leniency with your healthy eating efforts, or navigate a situation that occurs that’s out of your control e.g. a work lunch or a flat tyre preventing you from getting to the gym. Or just give you space to ‘get away with’ as much as possible. We want you to be able to dance the night away at your best friend's wedding until 4am, without worrying that you’re not getting 8 hours sleep!

    Remember that it's really about what you do most of the time, not about what you do every now and again that makes a difference.

title: Ditch the Scales
body:
If you weigh yourself regularly, we strongly recommend you ditch the scales.
If you can’t bring yourself to throw them out, at least bury them deep in a cupboard!

Body weight is too often used as a scale of success, when in reality no one but you even knows your body weight, and your worth does NOT come down to the number shown on the scales.

Body weight differs hugely between individuals based on height, muscle mass (did you know muscle weighs a lot more than body fat?), bone density and so much more, and our own weight will fluctuate day to day.

Body weight is too often negatively used as a tool of comparison, to both yourself and others.

We want you to ditch the concept of a ‘goal weight’ in this program, and instead focus on the positive changes that mean the most. This might be energy levels, happiness, muscle tone or fitness, or fitting into a smaller dress size (which is a much better measure of healthy changes to our body).

title: Before we get started
body:
This is by no means an exhaustive list, however, we’ve tried to narrow down the most important supplements for you, based on the latest research on your specific type of PCOS.  We don’t want you having to take hundreds of different supplements and so we’ve worked really hard to narrow these down to just the most important for you.

These are listed in order of importance, so if you only want to take 1-2, start with those at the top of this list.


  • These are just our suggestions, as always, please check with your doctor first before taking any new supplements, especially if you are on any medication

  • Please see the links below for where to order in different countries

  • Those marked with an asterix (*) contain herbs and are not recommended during pregnancy or breastfeeding

  • We strongly recommend finishing this module before ordering any supplements

title: Inositol
body:
When it comes to improving insulin, first up is inositol. Inositol is a naturally occurring compound in the body and it’s actually a really important messenger in our insulin pathway. As our insulin rises, we need more inositol to do its job and if we supplement, we might actually be able to improve our insulin sensitivity.

Studies have shown that inositol is the most effective supplement for insulin resistance in PCOS, and a 2019 analysis of the research found it to be as effective as metformin for improving insulin. However this doesn’t mean you have to choose - you can take both!


We recommend: Myo inositol

Dose: 4,000mg daily
 
For best results, take 2,000mg with breakfast, 2000mg with dinner

title: B Vitamins & Chromium
body:
B vitamins are very important for allowing your insulin to work properly. They’re also essential in a number of other processes including hormone production. Chromium is another mineral that’s essential in insulin sensitivity, and it’s really hard to get in your diet.

A 2017 review of all the research found that chromium had a positive effect in improving insulin, BMI and testosterone in people with PCOS.
A B vitamin blend is particularly beneficial for anyone taking Metformin, which strips the body of a number of essential nutrients, namely vitamin B12. If you are taking a prenatal, you will not need to take this blend.


We recommend: Jarrow’s Glucose Optimizer *

*Not to be taken whilst pregnant as it contains herbs.

Contains: B12 100mcg, 200mg chromium picollinate

Note: If you can’t find this blend, aim for a quality B vitamin blend and a separate chromium picollinate supplement.

title: Magnesium
body:
Magnesium is another essential mineral in the body, and it has an important role in our glucose metabolism and insulin action. It’s now thought that magnesium deficiency could be one of the predisposing factors to developing insulin resistance, and supplementation with magnesium has shown to increase insulin sensitivity in clinical trials.

And considering that 50% or more of the population of the US don’t get enough magnesium from their food, this is a good reason to supplement with magnesium when we’re wanting to increase our insulin sensitivity.

We recommend: Magnesium glycinate  

Dose: 400mg daily

For best results, take 200mg with breakfast, 200mg with dinner
